This is a great example of what “open-sourcing” data labelling can achieve. One the the greatest challenges in most ML researches is lack of quality data, not just because it’s hard to collect, but also because labelling and transcription can be extremely labor extensive. Any way to offload part of the labor from experts can help greatly.

Earthquakes can never be totally predicted by humans a 100% of the time. Perhaps 95% of the time, but definitely not 100%.

Have a look at the early warning systems used on Android phones where simultaneous accelerometer data from lots of phones in an area, caused by p waves from an earthquake, are used to send a warning to all phones in a region. I am in New Zealand where it has worked once a few months ago. The quake was about 10km away and the warning gave me just a couple of seconds before I felt the quake. Not long enough to get outside but long enough to drop, cover and hold. As it was the first time most people, me included, were still trying to figure out why their phone was making a noise when the quake hit but once they are used to it lives could be saved.

Extra low frequency radio waves  are usually emitted before actual movement, and I receive these waves for some reason. I have predicted several quakes, including the huge one in Ca. several years ago. I got waves four days prior, compared the date and time they were also received by a radiologist at Stanford, which is when I was able to identify what I was hearing. His receiver was coincidentally placed on the very fault near my home that the 7.3 quake occurred.  Since then I've predicted several more quakes.

As a computer scientist who doesn't work with coding AI very often, but who has some education in it and a strong interest, I don't think it can possibly be overstated: training. Data. Is. So. Important. For. AI. To. Work. Right. SO IMPORTANT. Not only the amount of data, but the quality and diversity of data, too. An AI can only learn from what it's trained on, it has no other experiences, so if your data doesn't represent all the types of data it will see "in the wild", it won't do a good job with that data that lies outside what it was trained on. Poor training data is how you get things like "racist AIs" that have trouble recognizing people of color, for instance. It's not that the AI is racist, it's that most of its training data was white people, so it doesn't understand anything else nearly as well as it understands white people.

The relevance, in case I wasn't clear, is in the way giving the earthquake AI training data from the study produced a significantly more accurate AI just a year later. That trend will continue: better training data = a better AI.

Interesting side note: this doesn't just apply to machine learning. It applies to people as well. Babies and young kids are ignorant of many things because they don't have enough training data. But reciting the common idea that older = wiser is also untrue, because many adults are ignorant (often dangerously so) despite their large amount of data because their data wasn't varied enough. In machine learning terminology, they had a large training set of poor quality data. You need a lot of data, but it must be diverse and high-quality data as well, otherwise both machines and humans fail to understand reality.
